## GAD-7 vs CAPE-42

GAD-7 vs CAPE-42 Psychologists, social scientists and researchers often face the challenge of questionnaires harmonisation between different studies. Navigating through lengthy PDFs and transcribing questions into Excel is undoubtedly not desirable. Luckily, the solution lies in Harmony, an advanced software tool designed precisely for this purpose. For example, if you are keen on comparing GAD-7 vs CAPE-42, Harmony using natural language processing and generative AI models could make your task much more effortless. Harmony's unique functionality allows for comparing GAD-7 vs CAPE-42 across different languages too. It relies on large language models to match instruments and gives a comparative percentage between each item in GAD-7 and CAPE-42. You can conveniently select instruments from Harmony's expansive database or drag and drop your own instruments in PDF form into Harmony's web interface. It significantly simplifies longitudinal analysis and fosters consistency across multiple studies. In the realm of harmonisation, GAD-7 vs CAPE-42 serves as a prime example. GAD-7 or Generalised Anxiety Disorder Assessment is a seven-item tool used to measure the severity of generalised anxiety disorder, while CAPE-42 or Community Assessment of Psychic Experience is a more complex questionnaire that assesses a wide range of psychic experiences. Crossing comparing these diverse instruments can offer unique insights and valuable data points for researchers. Harmony is the obvious choice for this task, making it an essential tool in the toolbox of every psychologist and researcher aiming to streamline their questionnaire analysis.

## Questions in GAD-7

|   No. | GAD-7 English                                                                                                                                      |
|------:|:---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|     1 | Feeling nervous, anxious, or on edge                                                                                                               |
|     2 | Not being able to stop or control worrying                                                                                                         |
|     3 | Worrying too much about different things                                                                                                           |
|     4 | Trouble relaxing                                                                                                                                   |
|     5 | Being so restless that it is hard to sit still                                                                                                     |
|     6 | Becoming easily annoyed or irritable                                                                                                               |
|     7 | Feeling afraid, as if something awful might happen                                                                                                 |
|     8 | If you checked any problems, how difficult have they made it for you to do your work, take care of things at home, or get along with other people? |
